awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Formation of Sulfur Aerosols in Fairbanks, Alaska
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is part of the broader effort, the Alaskan Layered Pollution and Chemical Analysis (ALPACA) research initiative and will also contribute to the NSF-funded SNAP-TEC (Sustainably Navigating Arctic Pollution through Engaging Communities) project that includes an intensive field campaign planned for the year 2022.  The goal of ALPACA is to better understand the chemical processing of air pollution during the cold and dark conditions in the wintertime in the Arctic. The objectives of SNAP-TEC are to improve the understanding of wintertime Arctic outdoor and indoor air pollution to assist in the sustainable development of the Arctic and improve air quality for Arctic peoples. Data from this project will become available to the public and other investigators who will be able to utilize it in assessing how to mitigate poor air quality in the wintertime in the Arctic.

Additional instrumentation will be deployed to improve the understanding of sulfur oxidation chemistry in the understudied high-latitude environment in Fairbanks, that is greatly impacted by both climate change and poor air quality. The PIs will investigate the formation routes and properties of hydroxymethane sulfonate (HMS) (HOCH2SO3-) in the atmosphere of Fairbanks. The PIs plan to collect online measurements of formaldehyde (HCHO) and PM2.5 inorganic sulfate and HMS with a PILS-IC (Particle-Into-Liquid Sampler coupled to an Ion Chromatograph). Measurements of gas and particle inorganic species that affect particle water and pH also will be measured, since HMS is formed through aqueous phase reactions that are sensitive to particle pH. Steady-state box model simulations will be conducted utilizing the data generated to examine the main chemical drivers of HMS formation in Fairbanks winter. This effort will examine the sensitivity of HMS formation to ambient HCHO and SO2 concentrations, meteorological conditions, aerosol liquid water, particle pH, and ionic strength.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project supported measurements of formaldehyde gas in wintertime Fairbanks, Alaska where air pollution is an issue. Formaldehyde is a chemically reactive air pollutant that is both emitted (e.g., vehicles, burning wood) and chemically produced in the air from chemistry of other air pollutants. In very cold environments like wintertime Fairbanks, formaldehyde can contribute to chemistry that makes particulate matter (PM) from sulfur-containing compounds. Breathing in airborne particulate matter, tiny solid or liquid particles suspended in the air, is bad for human health. The goal of this project was to better understand the chemistry that makes the sulfur-containing particulate matter under these cold, dark conditions.

The results of the project found that formaldehyde-involved chemistry does indeed form sulfur-containing particulate matter in wintertime Fairbanks during very cold periods. It also found that previous research likely overestimated the amount of these compounds because the measurement techniques could not perfectly distinguish these compounds from others. The results will help other researchers do a better job of differentiating the measured sulfur-containing compounds and help regulatory agencies more effectively improve the wintertime air quality in high latitude communities.

Products that resulted from this project include a formaldehyde data set for the Alaskan Layered Pollution and Chemical Analysis (ALPACA) measurement campaign period in 2022. Three scientific journal manuscripts using these data were written, with one published, one accepted, and one submitted. The latter two are:

Dingilian, Kayane, et al., Hydroxymethanesulfonate and Sulfur (IV) in Fairbanks Winter During the ALPACA Study. Submitted to ACS ES&T Air January 2024.

Simpson, William, et al., Overview of the Alaskan Layered Pollution and Chemical Analysis (ALPACA) Field Experiment. Accepted to ES&T Air February 2024.

Another publication may follow on the topic of formaldehyde sources in wintertime Fairbanks.
